text.p: These are the leading stories in the Pakistani press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- The National Assembly (lower house) unanimously adopted a motion for the formation of a select committee which would draft a constitutional amendment bill to initiate the process of accountability of people holding public office.
- The rupee fell against the dollar in the kerb market amid massive demand for the dollar spurred by political uncertainty.

- The government has hired the services of a senior executive of Merrill Lynch, a U.S.-based brokerage firm, to act as an adviser in its talks with a delegation of the U.S.-based credit rating agency Moody's Investors' Services Inc.
- The retail prices of vegetable ghee and cooking oil have risen by three rupees.
- Pakistan, eager to build trade ties with oil-rich Central Asian states, has postponed the departure of a planned truck convoy to the Kazakh capital Almaty, an official said.
- The State (central) Bank of Pakistan is likely to withdraw exchange risk cover available to banks on private foreign currency deposits.
- Bank of America announced it had entered into agreements with two state-run banks to finance wheat imports worth up to $125 million by the government of Pakistan.
- The United States and Pakistan have agreed to complete the process of delivering $370 million of military equipment, including three P-3C under the Brown Amendment by December 31.

- Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's special envoy Zafar Hilaly arrived in Tehran with a letter for Iranian President Ali Akbar Rafsanjani. He met Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati for talks on regional issues, including Afghanistan.
